citeinfo.othercit: This metadata file can be found at: ftp://cameron.cr.usgs.gov/pub/nbii_metadata/brdpwrc0003.txt (text format) and ftp://cameron.cr.usgs.gov/pub/nbii_metadata/brdpwrc0003.html (HTML format) and ftp://cameron.cr.usgs.gov/pub/nbii_metadata/brdpwrc0003.sgml (SGML format).

descript.abstract: Bird banding is a universal and indispensable technique for studying the movement, survival and behavior of birds. Data is collected by numerous permitted individuals in both countries. The North American Bird Banding Program is jointly administered by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Biological Resources Division and the Canadian Wildlife Service. Their respective banding offices have similar functions and policies and use the same bands, reporting forms and data formats. Joint coordination of the program dates back to 1923. In the U.S., the Bird Banding Laboratory (BBL) at Laurel, Maryland, functions as a service and administrative center for those who use the banding technique or banding data in their work. BBL issues permits and bands, supplies forms, instructional materials and technical advice, coordinates the use of auxiliary markers such as colored leg bands and radio transmitters, serves as the repository for banding data, serves as the clearinghouse for reports of banded birds, disseminates banding data to researchers and managers, and assists in the development and coordination of banding projects. BBL edits and inputs data into its Banding Encounter Database.
descript.purpose: Banding and encounter data are gathered and filed for the purpose of facilitating migratory bird research in North America. Waterfowl banding and encounter data are used by federal, state and provincial wildlife agencies in combination with other data sets, to help set federal hunting regulations. In addition, many states and provinces use banding and encounter data as a component of both game and nongame studies. Both banding and encounter data can be combined with other data for work on bird distribution, migration, survival, mortality, population size, and other demographic parameters.
descript.supplinf: The numerical codes in the data can be translated with the aid of the Banding Manual (described in the section 1.15 Cross Reference). Status code in the first column indicates that something was done to the bird upon recapture that changed the original status. Bird Encounter information can be viewed at http://www.mp1-pwrc.usgs.gov

timeperd.current: Data set began to be collected about 1900 and was computerized in the mid 1960's.

spdom.descgeog: Includes range of North American species. Range includes breeding, wintering and migration locations. Wintering ranges can include South America, Africa, Europe. Breeding can occur as far north as the Arctic. However, the species being studied are Nor

theme.themekey: Parameters: EARTH SCIENCE > BIOSPHERE > ZOOLOGY > BIRDS
Parameters: EARTH SCIENCE > BIOSPHERE > ECOLOGICAL DYNAMICS > ABUNDANCE

idinfo.accconst: Information may be withheld where endangered or threatened or sensitive species are involved. To protect their interests, a "Policy on Release" is included with each request, describing current limiting criteria.
idinfo.useconst: Bird Banding data maintained in the computer files have been gathered at a significant cost to the many persons and agencies who cooperate in the North American Bird Banding Program. These cooperators have certain proprietary interests in the data they produce. The person who first bands a bird has prior publication rights to any data resulting from that banding and/or subsequent encounter of that band. Information may be withheld where endangered or threatened or sensitive species are involved. To protect their interests, a "Policy on Release" is included with each request, describing current limiting criteria.

attracc.attraccr: Numerous edits in order to maintain high quality.

dataqual.complete: A summary record can represent from 1 to 100,000 birds. The summary records do not contain complete band number. All encounters from 1908 to present that have been reported. In this program are included all game birds from 1908 and all nongame birds from 1955 to present.

method.methdesc: There are numerous, highly variable techniques in bird banding and encounters.

overview.eaover: Entity - bird Associated Attribute - banding and recovery information. See Birding Banding Summary and Encounter files for specific details.

cntorgp.cntorg: Bird Banding Laboratory, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center, Biological Resources Division, U.S. Geological Survey (USGS)

distinfo.distliab: No warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from the Bird Banding Office Patuxent Wildlife Research Center Biological Resources Division (BRD) U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), or the Bird Banding Office of the National Wildlife Research Center (NWRC), and not indirectly though other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data. Neither the BRD, NWRC, nor the NASA Global Change Master Directory shall be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.
distinfo.custom: United States citizens should contact the Bird Banding Laboratory in Laurel, MD. Canadian citizens should contact the Bird Banding Office in Quebec, Canada. Contact information is given in section 6.1. The following information is needed to fill a data request: Justification or need for use of the data and how the data will be used. The type of data needed and format desired (paper, disk or both) which files are to be used - encounter retrieval file, banding retrieval file or both, the species, age, and sex, of interest, time period desired, the requester's name, permit number (if a bander), mailing address, daytime telephone number.
